channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Stop worrying about Go's error handling syntaxã€‘ä¸å†æ‹…å¿ƒGOçš„é”™è¯¯å¤„ç†è¯­æ³•
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹556 â€” June 4, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–Šï¸ I was meant to be travelling this week. My plans changed, but Iâ€™d already planned for a shorter issue, so itâ€™s a quicker one this time. Back to full service next week!
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

â€œFor the foreseeable future, the Go team will stop pursuing syntactic language changes for error handling. We will also close all open and incoming proposals that concern themselves primarily with the syntax of error handling, without further investigation.â€

___
Robert Griesemer and the Go team

[ On | No ] Syntactic Support for Error Handling â€” The topic of handling errors in Go, and if itâ€™s possible to improve the syntax around doing so, has been raised many times over the years, but sometimes itâ€™s worth drawing a line under things and to focus elsewhere. Robert explains the matter, some of the proposals made over the years, and the benefits of maintaining the statusÂ quo.

Robert Griesemer

The Guide to In-House Vs Managed Kubernetes-As-A-Service â€” Struggling with the â€œbuild vs. buyâ€ decision when it comes to Kubernetes infrastructure management? You're not alone! Download the guide to discover the pros and cons of each approach as we break down the associated costs, risks & ROI. Get itÂ today!

Fairwinds sponsor

Pure vs. Impure Iterators in Go â€” Go 1.23 introduced custom iterators, but the standard â€˜single-useâ€™ vs. not classification can be confusing. This post proposes a clearer pure vs. impure distinction, with concrete examples and performanceÂ insights.

Julien Cretel

IN BRIEF:

  • Even if you don't need it, this JavaScript Developer's Guide to Go is a primer that might suit someone on yourÂ team.

  • The latest annual Stack Overflow survey is now open â€“ check it out if you want to increase Go's representation in the resultsÂ :-)

Three Cool slog.Logger Tricks â€” Make slog.Logger sing with a few smart, composable loggingÂ patterns.

Joeson Huang

Simpler Backoff â€” Exponential backoff algorithms can be complex and difficult to reason about, or you can use a lookup table to make itÂ trivial.

Josh Bleecher Snyder

ğŸ“„ The Perils of Pointers in the Land of the Zero-Sized Type â€“ Pointergeist is definitely my favorite word of theÂ day. Fillmore Labs

ğŸ“º Making a Game in Go with No Experience â€“ Interesting to see someone totally new to Go leap in and use Ebitengine to produce resultsÂ quickly. Goodgis

ğŸ“„ Let's Write a JSON Parser from Scratch Sushant Dhiman

ğŸ“„ Cross-Compiling C and Go via cgo with Bazel Uros Popovic

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Bob 0.35: SQL Query Builder and ORM/Factory Generator â€” Though v0.36 and v0.37 have come out in just the past few days, v0.35 was a big milestone for Bob as it enabled the creation of code for SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE queries for Postgres, MySQL and SQLite. Numerous other improvements demand you give it another look too, though â€“ some examplesÂ here.

Stephen Afam-Osemene

ğŸ’¡ You might also find Bob vs GORM a usefulÂ comparison (there are also comparisons with Ent, SQLBoiler, and Jet over on theÂ left).

franz-go: A Complete Apache Kafka Client Library â€” A library that â€œaims to provide every Kafka feature from Apache Kafka v0.8.0 onwardâ€ and certainly has a strikingÂ featureset.

Travis Bischel

httpgrace: A net/http Wrapper with Graceful Shutdown â€” Rather than call http.ListenAndServe, the idea is you can call httpgrace.ListenAndServe and get graceful shutdown bakedÂ in.

Enrico Candino

  • MCP Go 0.31 â€“ An implementation of the Model Context ProtocolÂ (MCP).

  • Revive 1.10 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • dae 1.0 â€“ High-performance eBPF-based transparentÂ proxy.

  • FrankenPHP 1.7 â€“ Modern Go-powered PHP appÂ server.

  • Air 1.62 â€“ Live reload for Go apps.

  • pdfcpu 0.11 â€“ Go PDFÂ processor.

â­ A golden oldie..

go-binsize-treemap: Render a Visualization of Go Executable Space Usage â€” Easier to look at than explain in writing! Itâ€™s a tool that generates an SVG treemap of how the space inside a Go-built executable is used. Even when it's not useful, it's fun to lookÂ at.

Nikolay Dubina

- åœ¨KubernetesåŸºç¡€æ¶æ„ç®¡ç†æ–¹é¢æ­£åœ¨åŠªåŠ›è§£å†³â€œæ„å»ºä¸ä¹°å…¥â€å†³å®šï¼Ÿä½ å¹¶ä¸å­¤å•ï¼ä¸‹è½½æŒ‡å—ï¼Œä»¥å‘ç°æ¯ç§æ–¹æ³•çš„åˆ©å¼Šï¼Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬åˆ†è§£äº†ç›¸å…³çš„æˆæœ¬ï¼Œé£é™©å’ŒROIã€‚ ç«‹å³è·å–ï¼

- GO 1.23å¼•å…¥äº†è‡ªå®šä¹‰è¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ ‡å‡†çš„â€œä¸€æ¬¡æ€§â€ä¸ä¸åˆ†ç±»å¯èƒ½ä¼šä»¤äººå›°æƒ‘ã€‚è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« æå‡ºäº†æ›´æ¸…æ™°çš„çº¯ä¸ä¸çº¯å‡€çš„åŒºåˆ«ï¼Œå…·ä½“å®ä¾‹å’Œç»©æ•ˆè§è§£ã€‚

Julien Cretel

Josh Bleecher Snyder

ğŸ“„ Fillmore Labs

ğŸ“º goodgis

item.title: ã€Ian Lance Taylor takes a break from Goã€‘ä¼Šæ©Â·å…°æ–¯Â·æ³°å‹’ï¼ˆIan Lance Taylorï¼‰ä¼‘æ¯ä¸€ä¸‹
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹554 â€” May 14, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

ğŸ–Šï¸ I'm going to Google I/O next week, so Go Weekly will be taking a break and will return on May 28. If you happen to be at I/O too, say hi if you see an Englishman rambling on aboutÂ newsletters. I'm intrigued to see if Go gets any presenceÂ there.
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

Go Weekly

Ian Lance Taylor Has Left Google â€” One of the most active contributors to Go (and the initial creator of the Go frontend for GCC) has left Google and, in turn, the Go project, though he hopes to return as a contributor one day. As a commenter on the related Hacker News thread (which is packed with all sorts of conjecture) said: â€œItâ€™s hard to overstate the amount of service Ian provided to the GoÂ communityâ€

Ian Lance Taylor

New Experimental 'Green Tea' Garbage Collector â€” A proposal outlining a new span-based, â€œmemory-awareâ€ GC algorithm focused on small objects that improves spatial and temporal locality on modern multi-CPU systems by better exploiting memory topologies and cache hierarchies. Benchmarks are mixed, but itâ€™s early days. You can try it out today with gotip and itâ€™s slated to be an opt-in experiment in GoÂ 1.25.

Knyszek and Clements

Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go, the language trusted by tech giants! Connect to Postgres, implement auth, and write tests that matter. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with GoÂ daily.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Which Go Router Should I Use? â€” Alex looks at some popular routing options, citing the pros and cons of each and wrapping it up with a nice decision flowchart and a list of other routing options. Weâ€™ve linked to this before but heâ€™s updated it forÂ 2025.

Alex Edwards

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ GopherCon UK takes place this August but its CFP closes this Saturday.

  • ğŸ¦‹ If you use Bluesky at all, someone's put together a 'starter pack' of Go contributors you can follow there.

Centralize HTTP Error Handling in Go â€” A nice pattern to clean up your HTTP handlers by creating a custom error and wrapperÂ function.

Alexis Bouchez

ğŸ“„ Using the OpenAI Responses API in Go â€“ A full walkthrough for OpenAIâ€™s latest way to interact with itsÂ LLMs. Chris Sotherden

ğŸ“„ Monitoring a Go App with Prometheus and Grafana Pradumna Saraf and Docker

ğŸ“„ sync.WaitGroup: Powerful, but Tricky.. Jens Neuse

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

pdfcpu: A PDF Processing and Manipulation Library â€” You can validate and optimize PDFs, split them, merge PDFs together, extract elements, and more. The latest version adds support for digital signature validation and improved image handling. GitHubÂ repo.

pdfcpu

Outpost: Outbound Webhooks and Event Destinations Infrastructure â€” A way to add reliable outbound webhooks and events to your apps with support for destination types such as Amazon EventBridge, AWS SQS, AWS SNS, GCP Pub/Sub, RabbitMQ, andÂ Kafka.

Hookdeck

Go Panicked Again? Yeah, Sentry Saw Itâ€”and Kept the Receipts â€” Goroutines are greatâ€”until one quietly dies. Sentry catches panics, traces them back, and gives you full context. ğŸ‘‰ Try it free before your next deploy getsÂ weird.

Sentry sponsor

Fx 36.0: A Command-Line JSON Processing Tool â€” If youâ€™ve got some files full of JSON that you want to slice and dice, Fx is for you. Notably, v36 adds support for streaming JSON and tailing such streams, itâ€™s also much faster and less memory hungry when parsing the largest of JSON files. A solid update for a very handyÂ tool.

Anton Medvedev

Goldmark: A Markdown Parser Written in Go â€” Pure Go, easy to extend, and CommonMark compliant (which GitHub-Flavored Markdown is based upon). Thereâ€™s also a WebAssembly powered Goldmark playground you canÂ try.

Yusuke Inuzuka

Compress: Optimized Compression Packages for Go â€” Covers a variety of compression standards like zstandard, S2, gzip, snappy, andÂ zip.

Klaus Post

UPX 5.0: The 'Ultimate Packer' for EXecutables â€” Staying on the theme of compression.. UPX is a tool that adds run-time compression and decompression to executables to reduce their size. Itâ€™s not Go specific but can work on Go executables as Ben Boyter discovered back inÂ 2019.

Oberhumer, Molnar, and Reiser

  • ğŸ“Š go-echarts 2.5.4 â€“ Charting and data visualization library that uses ApacheÂ ECharts. You can see examples in theÂ docs.

  • FerretDB 2.2 â€“ A database that acts like MongoDB but uses Postgres forÂ storage.

  • go-github 72.0 â€“ Go client library for accessing the GitHub APIÂ v3.

  • pgroll 0.12 â€“ Zero-downtime, reversible schema migrations forÂ Postgres.

  • purego 0.8.3 â€“ Library for calling C functions from Go without Cgo.

  • Buf 1.54 â€“ CLI tool for working with ProtocolÂ Buffers.

  • ğŸ¤– Go OpenAI 1.40 â€“ An OpenAI API wrapperÂ library.

ğŸ˜ Did You Know..?

As much as we enjoy making this newsletter, we also publish a handful of others you might not know about. You can see the latest issues of them all directly on theirÂ homepages:

ğŸ’ Ruby Weekly was our first ever newsletter, and it's still going strong 749 issues later! Unsurprisingly it's for Ruby and Rails enthusiasts.

ğŸ’› JavaScript Weekly covers all things JavaScript, but also the JS ecosystem more broadly, including TypeScript, WebAssembly, Vue.js, build tools, andÂ Svelte.

âš›ï¸ Just round the corner from JS is React Status covering, unsurprisingly, the React world and Node Weekly which goes deeper into Node.js, the npm ecosystem, and other server-side JS runtimes like Deno andÂ Bun.

ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» Frontend Focus covers everything that appears browser-side! CSS, HTML, accessibility, WebGPU, browser updates â€“ it's all in there.

ğŸ˜ Last, but not least, Postgres Weekly rounds out the family. It's the smallest newsletter, but always packed with great stuff as the Postgres ecosystem punches above its weight in terms of news and interestingÂ releases.

__
Peter Cooper, your editor

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

ğŸ’ rubyâ€‹â€‹ weekly deverly æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰å²ä»¥æ¥çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°é—»ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬çš„ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°é—»ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”åœ¨ä»¥åä»ç„¶æœ‰749ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ï¼æ¯«ä¸å¥‡æ€ªï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯é’ˆå¯¹Rubyå’ŒRailsçˆ±å¥½è€…çš„ã€‚

ğŸ’› JavaScript Weekly covers all things JavaScript, but also the JS ecosystem more broadly, including TypeScript, WebAssembly, Vue.js, build tools,å’ŒSvelteã€‚

âš›ï¸åªæ˜¯ä»JSåˆ°æ‹è§’å¤„ï¼Œ node Weekly æ›´æ·±å…¥node.jsï¼ŒNode.jsï¼ŒNPM Ecosystemï¼Œä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–æœåŠ¡å™¨å¼JSå’Œå…¶ä»–Server-Side JS Runtime denoå’ŒdeNO ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» frontend focus è¦†ç›–ä¼¼ä¹æµè§ˆå™¨è¾¹çš„ä¸€åˆ‡ï¼ CSSï¼ŒHTMLï¼Œå¯è®¿é—®æ€§ï¼ŒWebGPUï¼Œæµè§ˆå™¨æ›´æ–° - éƒ½åœ¨å…¶ä¸­ã€‚

ğŸ˜æœ€åä½†å¹¶éæœ€ä¸é‡è¦çš„ä¸€ç‚¹æ˜¯ï¼Œ Postgres Weekly Weekly ä¸€å›åˆå®¶äººã€‚è¿™æ˜¯æœ€å°çš„æ–°é—»é€šè®¯ï¼Œä½†åœ¨æ–°é—»å’Œæœ‰è¶£çš„å‘è¡Œç‰ˆä¸­ï¼ŒPostgresç”Ÿæ€ç³»ç»Ÿçš„é‡é‡è¶…è¿‡å…¶é‡é‡ã€‚

__
Peter Cooperï¼Œæ‚¨çš„ç¼–è¾‘

item.title: ã€Go in the Google I/O spotlightã€‘è¿›å…¥Google I/O Spotlight
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹555 â€” May 28, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

â–¶Â Â What's New in Go: Google's Take â€” Released as part of last weekâ€™s Google I/O, Goâ€™s project lead and lead devrel team up to present an extensive list of recent additions and improvements to Go. Itâ€™s good to see Google presenting an official roundup and thereâ€™s more depth in 20 minutes than you might expect (though you can skip the first few minutes which is essentially a pitch for theÂ language).

Google

2x-40x Faster Docker Builds with Blacksmith â€” With a one-line code change, Blacksmith can make your Docker builds incremental by mounting your Docker layer cache into your GitHub Actions runner. Blacksmith is used by 600+ companies like Ashby, Clerk, andÂ Mintlify.

Blacksmith sponsor

The Results of Go's Cryptography Security Audit â€” The core team brought in an external security firm to audit Goâ€™s cryptography packages, resulting in a single low-severity issue in an unsupported integration (fixed in Go 1.24) and various other findings. The team also explains some other security enhancements coming to GoÂ soon.

Roland Shoemaker and Filippo Valsorda

IN BRIEF:

  • John Reilly reflects on the recent adoption of Go for reimplementing TypeScript in a native manner and why Go is 'the pragmatic choice' ofÂ language.

  • The Go-powered FrankenPHP PHP application server is now officially supported by the PHP Foundation.

  • A developer put seven languages (including Go) under a heavy stress test to see how they'd cope. Go 'performed admirably' but its GC eventually fellÂ behind.

Solving Flaky Tests with Go 1.24's synctest â€” Goroutine scheduling can introduce hard-to-debug complexity to tests, but Go 1.24â€™s synctest package can make it easier to test concurrent code by introducing isolated â€˜bubblesâ€™ to keep things coordinated and moreÂ deterministic.

Phuong Le

The Generics Way to Use GORM â€” GORM is a popular ORM library for Go and its latest release (v1.30.0) has added support for using generics. This post shows off theÂ benefits.

Jinzhu

CodeRabbitâ€™s Free AI Code Reviews in IDE - VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf â€” AI code reviews in VS Code, Cursor & Windsurf: line-by-line checks, one-click fixes & code-aware feedback - free in your IDE. InstallÂ now.

CodeRabbit sponsor

ğŸ“„ Taking More Control Over Your Cobra CLI Documentation â€“ A tip for those using the Cobra CLIÂ framework. Jamie Tanna

ğŸ“„ Another Tale of go.mod Bloat Ted Unangst

ğŸ“„ Working with JSON Web Tokens in Go Alex Pliutau

ğŸ“º Coding a MySQL Database Proxy for Fun Package Main

ğŸ“º Building a Minesweeper Game with Go and Raylib Package Main

ğŸ“„ An Experiment in Using Git as S3 Kris Tun

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

chafa-go: Render Images in the Terminal with Chafa â€” Go bindings for Chafa, a C library that uses smart combinations of Unicode symbols to render graphics in terminal environments (or pass images through to terminal emulators with direct image rendering abilities). It uses purego to avoid needing CGO but does need GoÂ 1.24.

Konstantinos Artopoulos

FSBroker: Broker, Group, Dedup, and Filter FSNotify Events â€” A library that sits on top of fsnotify (which works cross-platform) and converts raw file system events into a more usableÂ form.

Hazem Elshabini

godump: A Pretty-Printer and Debug Dumper for Structs â€” Inspired by a similar feature in Laravel, this library lets you print structs, slices, maps, and more, in an easy to read fashion at theÂ terminal.

Chris Miles

vipsgen: Go Binding Generator for libvips â€” libvps is a popular and efficient image processing library. vipsgen lets you generate Go bindings against a libvips install that are type-safe, robust, and fullyÂ documented.

Adrian Shum

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Course: Complete Go for Professional Developers â€” Craft production-grade APIs with Go. Taught by a Twitch ML engineer who solves real problems with Go daily.

  • TableWriter 1.0.7 â€“ Render rich text tables in ASCII, Unicode, Markdown, and at theÂ terminalÂ (see above).

  • Gnet v2.8 â€“ High-perf, non-blocking event loop networkingÂ library.

  • Joker 1.5 â€“ A small Clojure interpreter andÂ linter.

  • go-redis 9.9 â€“ Official Go Redis clientÂ library.

  • webdav 5.8 â€“ Standalone WebDAVÂ server.

  • Roaring 2.5 â€“ Roaring bitmaps for Go.

ğŸ•¹ï¸ And one for fun..

Night Knight: A 60 FPS Go Remake of an 80's Videogame â€” A reader and their partner made an Ebitengine powered retro game, converted from a game originally on the 1980â€™s MSX home computer. Itâ€™s available to download for WindowsÂ only.

Anca and Claus

ğŸ˜… I've been 'vibe coding' my own Go 3D game too â€“ it's been a lot of fun and definitely a learningÂ experience..

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>

konstantinos artopoulos

Adrian Shum

item.title: ã€Does Go need bare metal support?ã€‘å»éœ€è¦è£¸æœºæ”¯æ’‘å—ï¼Ÿ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹553 â€” May 7, 2025

UnsubÂ Â |Â Â WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Practical Patterns for Graceful Shutdowns â€” Shutting down gracefully can mean the difference between a good user experience with consistent data and angry users (or even just yourself!) with corrupted data. Follow and adapt this five-step approach, and shutting down wonâ€™t open you up toÂ issues.

Phuong Le (VictoriaMetrics)

Proposal: Add Bare Metal Support to Go? â€” Andrea proposes a new 'none' target for the Go compiler to enable freestanding execution without direct OS support. This isnâ€™t exactly new ground â€“ itâ€™s been proposed before â€“ but Go contributor Filippo Valsorda thinks itâ€™s worth serious consideration again due to the opportunities it would open up in micro VMs, firmware, andÂ elsewhere.
